userreviews.userReview: The adventures of Miss Julia is captured by Ann B. Ross in this popular series. While this is not high literature, I thoroughly enjoy the situations that Miss Julia finds herself in. She is like a madcap Angela Lansbury careening through her small southern town trying to please everyone while dealing with her many personal crazy friends and relations. These are hilarious and often you can't put them down. I don't know why they never made this into a comedy series.
Miss Julia books always make me laugh out loud at least once! Great to listen to!
I really have been enjoying this series, but this book has several laugh out loud passages. I have to spell it out because Miss Julia would never approve of LOL.....
Listened to the book while traveling. Miss Julia never lets me down!

Not my favourite in the series, but a fun read. The religion and small town gossip thread got to me after a while. I lived in the South and I live in a small town, so I understand how important/detrimental it can be, but it's not a lot to build a whole book on. The previous one Miss Julia Hits the Road and number one were much more fun. Still, this did have one of the best lines ever to end the book with. Loved it!

How can I not give a whole bunch of stars to someone who makes me laugh so much. This was another Miss Julia book. The title character is a wealthy southern woman "of a certain age" with definite opinions about her the others in her narrow-minded small southern town. She comes across as very naive. All the characters in the series are very colorful. These books are a great comic relief and a lot of fun for me.

I gave this book only two stars not because it was bad, it wasn't that bad, but it just wasn't at all what I expected. I expect someone to die in cozy mysteries, with the balance being on solving the "who-done-it" with some frivolity thrown in. Unfortunately, though, this book was entirely about small town church gossip of who had an affair with whom. Just not for me!
If you love- " I Love Lucy" then Miss Julia Books are for you! Hilarious hi-jinks!

Audio rendition. Perfect narrator. Delightful, what other word could best describe a Miss Julia book? Miss Julia has a big decision to make, will she marry beau Sam or not? While she’s contemplating her big decision, life in this southern town goes on. I had a few laugh out loud moments while listening.
And what a wonderful match it is!!For all us southern gals, raised to be gracious ladies, I'm afraid the hilarity of the tent meeting will have us all guffawing! Brilliant work Ms. Ross!!

I hope they redo the first few Miss Julia books with Cynthia Darlow, as the reader. She's incredible and I missed her reading on this book. Enjoyed the story, but wasn't the same reading with the ears, without Cynthia Darlow. She makes it a hoot!

No disappointment here!I have enjoyed reading Miss Julia's adventures since the first one I read! She never fails to be entertaining. It's fun to see what mischief she gets herself in - and she always does.

Another fantastic entry in the series! The humor in this novel is on point, and doesn't give up. I'm also glad that a plot device that's been unresolved I'm every novel has finally come to fruition. Can't wait for the next one!
She’s enjoyable and feisty. Always a worthy listen.
Excellent read!
Fun reading for Valentine's week.
Possibly my favorite Miss Julia book to date. There are quite variety of adventures that go into this book. And, Miss Julia is involved in a budding romance. A very relaxing and enjoyable read.
Not coherent. no real reason. for many of the actions taken by the lead characters. the plot had really good bits but they don't hang together well
Miss Julia is involved in a comic sort of Peyton Place in this book, and the Holy Land theme park? Laughing! I'm off to snag 2 more titles in the series!
Miss Julia finally meets the one person she cannot intimidate.
I laughed and laughed!
I really enjoyed listening to Miss Julia and the antics she gets in. I'm gonna have to go back to the first in the series to get all of Miss Julia's southern glory.
My least favorite book in the series so far, but still gave me a couple laugh-out-loud moments. Lots of gossip and ulterior motives in this one.
really love Miss Julia and her spunk
Miss Julia has met her match in Mr. Sam. Hmmm I wonder what will happen?

Miss Julia and I haven't spent any time together for awhile so it took me awhile to re-acclimate to her mindset and ideas. This book has her considering the marriage proposal of her long time friend but short time beau, Sam. He wants to change Miss Julia's widow status to new bride. Though Sam is a much better man than her late husband, Miss Julia has her doubts.To prove her independence she makes a hasty and it turns out bad business deal that weaves throughout the book. She gets word that the aforementioned late husband may have been more of a philanderer than she first suspected. Miss Julia wants to keep it quiet not to protect her reputation but the feelings of her husband's illegitimate son that she has come to love.In the meantime, a local comes home and Miss Julia decides to welcome her who used to be a him back to town with a reception. It's not charity so much as curiosity and a chance to deflect the talk about her late husband.The book was written more than 10 years ago so it's interesting to see how far attitudes have come and yet not come while reading this. I could have done without Lillian's granddaughter, but I continue to be a fan of Lillian and Sam who both have Miss Julia's back.

A truly irascible southern woman! I like the Miss Julia series of books for the humor and audacity of the main character, Miss Julia Springer. She goes to great lengths to solve everyone's problems while maintaining her desire not to be involved. In this book, Miss Julia's beau, Sam, is not to be put off when it comes to marriage, slanderous gossip abounds about the preacher's wife when she begins to wear make-up and flirt with a wealthy out of towner, and someone has spotted the preacher's secretary at an out of the way motel with the mayor. All this and a company of religious fanatics who want to build a Walk Where Jesus Walked Theme Park on Miss Julia's land, and a good friend's son returns to town sporting a new look--as a woman. Miss Julia is kept busy trying to straighten things out in her usual no nonsense meddling.

Miss Julia is a character I have really come to love and cherish. She is set in her ways, somewhat cranky, yet her many adventures are a delight to read. Miss Julia has lived her life a certain way defined by what her church and husband strong-armed her into for over forty years, so it is perfectly understandable that she would be hesitant before pursing a relationship with Sam. I think this book (so far) has been my favorite book in the Miss Julia series. Not only for her agonizing about a marriage with Sam but Ms. Ross' depiction of how often (more times than not) there is corruption within religious groups, from the crooked religious amusement park to the fornication between her pastor's secretary and a financial banker of the amusement park.

I didn't particularly like this book. The Hippocracy of the main character drive me nuts. She seemed to flip flop between chapters between not caring at all what anyone else thought and caring so much that she was willing to throw everyone else under the bus to get herself to look better. In the end it just got kind of old, I kept wanting something more to happen in the plot. I also felt like the author threw all the controversial things she could think of for the town to deal with in one book just for fun. Sometimes the storyline want very clear because she was introducing a new gossip chain so soon.

In this one, Julia sells a parcel of land to be developed as a Walk Where Jesus Walked theme park, and then regrets it. More scandal about her late husband arises, which she tries to protect Hazel Marie, and Lloyd from, and meanwhile, gossip flies around the town, and nearly everyone is involved in some of it. Her close friend's son comes back to town as a daughter, and the pastor's wife explores a bit of fashion, much to his dismay. It's sort of a lot of ado about nothing, but quite amusing. And of course the title implies that there will be some progress in Julia and Sam's courtship. I enjoyed this story as much as the others in this series.

description: With devoted fans across the country, Miss Julia, that endearingly sharp-tongued southern belle of a certain age, has no shortage of admirers. But in Miss Julia Meets Her Match, our feisty heroine must come to terms with her most ardent admirer of all: longtime beau Sam Murdoch, who wants to tie the knot. While it’s hard to resist Sam’s charm, Miss Julia isn't about to give up her independence so easily. After all, there are plenty of other matters that require her attention, including a Holy Land theme park to be built on her property, a possible affair between the mayor and the preacher’s secretary, and the arrival of her housekeeper Lillian’s five-year-old pistol of a great-granddaughter. In the midst of all the commotion, can her cool-as-a-cucumber head help her heart make the decision of a lifetime?
title:
Miss Julia Meets Her Match
      
          (Miss Julia #5)
